content_blocks.h2: Mistake #1: Wet or Greasy Seal Area
content_blocks.problem: Moisture or grease on the bag's sealing edge prevents proper heat sealing, causing weak spots that leak air.
content_blocks.solution: Always pat the sealing area dry with a paper towel before sealing. For greasy foods, fold the bag edge over to create a clean sealing surface.
content_blocks.pro_tip: Keep a roll of paper towels next to your sealer—you'll use them constantly.

content_blocks.h2: Mistake #2: Using the Wrong Mode for Your Food
content_blocks.problem: Using 'Dry' mode on moist foods or 'Moist' mode on dry foods leads to over-vacuuming or weak seals.
content_blocks.solution: Use 'Moist' or 'Gentle' mode for juicy meats, soft fruits, and anything with liquid. Use 'Dry' mode for hard items like nuts, crackers, or pre-frozen foods.
content_blocks.pro_tip: When in doubt, start with gentle/pulse mode—you can always vacuum more, but you can't un-crush delicate foods.

content_blocks.problem: Cramming too much food into one bag prevents proper air removal and creates stress points that can tear.
content_blocks.solution: Leave 3-4 inches of space at the top and don't pack bags more than 2/3 full. Use multiple smaller bags instead of one overstuffed bag.
content_blocks.pro_tip: Flat, single-layer packs vacuum better and stack more efficiently in your freezer.

content_blocks.problem: Liquid gets sucked into the vacuum chamber, contaminating the machine and preventing proper sealing.
content_blocks.solution: Pre-freeze soups, stews, and marinades for 30-60 minutes until slushy, or use a chamber sealer designed for liquids.
content_blocks.pro_tip: Tilt your external sealer so the vacuum port is higher than the bag opening when sealing liquids.

content_blocks.h2: Mistake #5: Using Damaged or Wrong Bag Type
content_blocks.problem: Punctured bags, smooth bags in external sealers, or bags not rated for freezing cause seal failures.
content_blocks.solution: Always inspect bags for holes before use. Use embossed/textured bags with external sealers, smooth bags with chamber sealers. Choose freezer-grade bags for long-term storage.
content_blocks.pro_tip: Buy bags in bulk from generic suppliers—they're often 50% cheaper than brand-name bags with identical performance.

content_blocks.h2: Mistake #6: Sealing Sharp or Pointed Foods
content_blocks.problem: Bones, shells, and sharp edges puncture bags during vacuuming or storage, causing air leaks.
content_blocks.solution: Wrap sharp edges in paper towels or parchment paper before bagging. Consider removing bones or using thicker bags for bone-in cuts.
content_blocks.pro_tip: Double-bag items with sharp edges, or use a rigid container with vacuum attachment instead.

content_blocks.problem: Stacking heavy items on vacuum bags or storing at wrong temperatures can cause seal failure or food spoilage.
content_blocks.solution: Store vacuum bags flat in single layers when possible. Keep frozen items at 0°F or below, refrigerated items at 40°F or below.
content_blocks.pro_tip: Label bags with contents AND date—vacuum-sealed food lasts so long you'll forget what's what.

faq.q: Why do my vacuum seals keep failing?
faq.a: The most common cause is moisture or grease on the sealing area. Always pat the bag edge dry before sealing and use the appropriate mode for your food type.
You can reuse bags that stored dry goods after washing, but never reuse bags that contained raw meat, fish, or dairy products due to food safety concerns.

faq.q: How long should vacuum sealed food last?
faq.a: Properly vacuum sealed food lasts 3-5 times longer than traditional storage. Frozen meats can last 2-3 years, while refrigerated items typically last 1-2 weeks.

faq.q: What's the difference between pulse and continuous vacuum?
faq.a: Pulse mode gives you control over vacuum strength, perfect for delicate foods. Continuous mode provides maximum vacuum for long-term storage of sturdy items.
